etymology.description: Pictogram: a broom with bristles on top and a tied handle below; modern form resembles roughly 肀 + 冖 + 巾 (top like 聿/肀/彐).
etymology.interpretation: Originally a drawn image of a broom—bristles above and a bound handle below. Later forms made the top look like components such as 聿/肀/彐 over a cloth-like 巾, but these are visual resemblances rather than functional phonetic or semantic parts.

examples.chinese: 她拿起扫帚(她拿起掃帚)，开始打扫院子(開始打掃院子)。
examples.pinyin: Tā ná qǐ sào zhǒu, kāi shǐ dǎ sǎo yuàn zi.
examples.english: She picked up the broom and began to clean the yard.

examples.chinese: 他用扫帚把地上的落叶扫成一堆(他用掃帚把地上的落葉掃成一堆)。
examples.pinyin: Tā yòng sào zhǒu bǎ dì shàng de luò yè sǎo chéng yī duī.
examples.english: He used a broom to sweep the fallen leaves on the ground into a pile.

examples.chinese: 请把扫帚放回墙角(請把掃帚放回牆角)。
examples.pinyin: Qǐng bǎ sào zhǒu fàng huí qiáng jiǎo.
examples.english: Please put the broom back in the corner.
